A **tropical cyclone** is a rapidly rotating [storm system](/wiki/Storm
"Storm") characterized by a [low-pressure](/wiki/Low-pressure_area "Low-
pressure area") center, a closed low-level atmospheric circulation, [strong
winds](/wiki/Beaufort_scale "Beaufort scale"), and a spiral arrangement of
[thunderstorms](/wiki/Thunderstorm "Thunderstorm") that produce heavy rain.
Depending on its location and strength, a tropical cyclone is referred to by
different names, including hurricane ([/ˈhʌrɪkən,
-keɪn/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")),[1][2][3]
[typhoon](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone#Hurricane_or_typhoon "Tropical cyclone")
([/taɪˈfuːn/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")), tropical storm,
cyclonic storm, [tropical
depression](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone#Tropical_depression "Tropical cyclone"),
and simply cyclone.[4] A [hurricane](/wiki/Atlantic_hurricane "Atlantic
hurricane") is a tropical cyclone that occurs in the [Atlantic
Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean") and northeastern [Pacific
Ocean](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean "Pacific Ocean") and a [typhoon](/wiki/Typhoon
"Typhoon") occurs in the northwestern Pacific Ocean; while in the south
Pacific or [Indian Ocean](/wiki/Indian_Ocean "Indian Ocean"), comparable
storms are referred to simply as “tropical cyclones” or “severe cyclonic
storms”.[4]

“Tropical” refers to the geographical origin of these systems, which form
almost exclusively over [tropical](/wiki/Tropics "Tropics") seas. “Cyclone”
refers to their winds moving in a circle,[5] whirling round their central
clear [eye](/wiki/Eye_\(cyclone\) "Eye \(cyclone\)"), with their winds blowing
[counterclockwise](/wiki/Clockwise_and_counterclockwise "Clockwise and
counterclockwise") in the [Northern Hemisphere](/wiki/Northern_Hemisphere
"Northern Hemisphere") and blowing clockwise in the [Southern
Hemisphere](/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere "Southern Hemisphere"). The opposite
direction of circulation is due to the [Coriolis effect](/wiki/Coriolis_effect
"Coriolis effect"). Tropical cyclones [typically
form](/wiki/Tropical_cyclogenesis "Tropical cyclogenesis") over large bodies
of relatively warm water. They derive their energy through the evaporation of
[water](/wiki/Water "Water") from the [ocean](/wiki/Ocean "Ocean") surface,
which ultimately [recondenses](/wiki/Condensation "Condensation") into
[clouds](/wiki/Cloud "Cloud") and rain when moist air rises and cools to
[saturation](/wiki/Saturated_fluid "Saturated fluid"). This [energy
source](/wiki/Energy_source "Energy source") differs from that of [mid-
latitude cyclonic storms](/wiki/Extratropical_cyclone "Extratropical
cyclone"), such as [nor'easters](/wiki/Nor%27easter "Nor'easter") and
[European windstorms](/wiki/European_windstorm "European windstorm"), which
are fueled primarily by [horizontal temperature
contrasts](/wiki/Baroclinic_instability "Baroclinic instability"). Tropical
cyclones are typically between 100 and 2,000 km (62 and 1,243 mi) in diameter.

The strong rotating winds of a tropical cyclone are a result of the
[conservation of angular momentum](/wiki/Conservation_of_angular_momentum
"Conservation of angular momentum") imparted by the [Earth](/wiki/Earth
"Earth")'s [rotation](/wiki/Earth%27s_rotation "Earth's rotation") as air
flows inwards toward the axis of rotation. As a result, they rarely form
within 5° of the equator.[6] Tropical cyclones are also almost completely
absent from Earth’s southwestern quartersphere, mainly because the shapes of
the African and South American continents permit the
[Benguela](/wiki/Benguela_Current "Benguela Current") and [Humboldt
Currents](/wiki/Humboldt_Current "Humboldt Current") to cover ocean basins as
far north as 5˚N with excessively cool water. These powerful cold currents
also produce much stronger [vertical wind shear](/wiki/Vertical_wind_shear
"Vertical wind shear") in the South Atlantic and Southeast Pacific, which
typically prevent tropical depressions and minor storms there from developing
into cyclones and prevent even the waters of the [Brazil
Current](/wiki/Brazil_Current "Brazil Current") from being so hot as analogous
western boundary currents or ocean gyres. Also, the [African easterly
jet](/wiki/African_easterly_jet "African easterly jet") and areas of
atmospheric instability which gives rise to cyclones in the Atlantic Ocean and
Caribbean Sea, along with [the Asian monsoon](/wiki/Monsoon_of_South_Asia
"Monsoon of South Asia") and [Western Pacific Warm
Pool](/wiki/Western_Pacific_Warm_Pool "Western Pacific Warm Pool"), are
feature of the Northern Hemisphere and Australia.

Coastal regions are particularly vulnerable to the impact of a tropical
cyclone, compared to inland regions. The primary energy source for these
storms is warm ocean waters, therefore these forms are typically strongest
when over or near water, and weaken quite rapidly over land. Coastal damage
may be caused by strong winds and rain, high waves (due to winds), [storm
surges](/wiki/Storm_surge "Storm surge") (due to severe pressure changes), and
[the potential](/wiki/Tornadogenesis "Tornadogenesis") of spawning
[tornadoes](/wiki/Tornado "Tornado"). Tropical cyclones also draw in air from
a large area—which can be a vast area for the most severe cyclones—and
concentrate the [precipitation](/wiki/Precipitation "Precipitation") of the
water content in that air (made up from atmospheric moisture and moisture
evaporated from water) into a much smaller area. This continual replacement of
moisture-bearing air by new moisture-bearing air after its moisture has fallen
as rain, may cause extremely heavy rain and river flooding up to 40 kilometres
(25 mi) from the coastline, far beyond the amount of water that the local
atmosphere holds at any one time.

Though their effects on human populations are often devastating, tropical
cyclones can relieve [drought](/wiki/Drought "Drought") conditions. They also
carry heat energy away from the tropics and transport it toward
[temperate](/wiki/Temperate "Temperate") [latitudes](/wiki/Latitude
"Latitude"), which may play an important role in modulating regional and
global [climate](/wiki/Climate "Climate").

## Physical structure

See also: [Eye (cyclone)](/wiki/Eye_\(cyclone\) "Eye \(cyclone\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Hurricane-
en.svg/290px-Hurricane-en.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Hurricane-en.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Hurricane-en.svg "Enlarge")

Diagram of a Northern hemisphere hurricane

Tropical cyclones are areas of relatively [low pressure](/wiki/Low-
pressure_area "Low-pressure area") in the [troposphere](/wiki/Troposphere
"Troposphere"), with the largest pressure perturbations occurring at low
altitudes near the surface. On Earth, the pressures recorded at the centers of
tropical cyclones are among the lowest ever observed at [sea
level](/wiki/Sea_level "Sea level").[7] The environment near the center of
tropical cyclones is warmer than the surroundings at all altitudes, thus they
are characterized as “warm core” systems.[8]

### Wind field

The near-surface wind field of a tropical cyclone is characterized by air
rotating rapidly around a [center of circulation](/wiki/Eye_\(cyclone\) "Eye
\(cyclone\)") while also flowing radially inwards. At the outer edge of the
storm, air may be nearly calm; however, due to the Earth’s rotation, the air
has non-zero [absolute angular momentum](/wiki/Absolute_angular_momentum
"Absolute angular momentum"). As air flows radially inward, it begins to
[rotate cyclonically](/wiki/Cyclonic_rotation "Cyclonic rotation") (counter-
clockwise in the Northern Hemisphere, and clockwise in the Southern
Hemisphere) in order to [conserve angular
momentum](/wiki/Conservation_of_angular_momentum "Conservation of angular
momentum"). At an inner radius, air begins to ascend to the [top of the
troposphere](/wiki/Tropopause "Tropopause"). This radius is typically
coincident with the inner radius of the [eyewall](/wiki/Eyewall "Eyewall"),
and has the strongest near-surface winds of the storm; consequently, it is
known as the _[radius of maximum winds](/wiki/Radius_of_maximum_wind "Radius
of maximum wind")_.[9] Once aloft, air flows away from the storm's center,
producing a shield of [cirrus clouds](/wiki/Cirrus_cloud "Cirrus cloud").[10]

The previously mentioned processes result in a wind field that is nearly
[axisymmetric](/wiki/Axisymmetric "Axisymmetric"): Wind speeds are low at the
center, increase rapidly moving outwards to the radius of maximum winds, and
then decay more gradually with radius to large radii. However, the wind field
often exhibits additional spatial and temporal variability due to the effects
of localized processes, such as [thunderstorm
activity](/wiki/Atmospheric_convection "Atmospheric convection") and
horizontal [flow instabilities](/wiki/Instability#Fluid_instabilities
"Instability"). In the vertical direction, winds are strongest near the
surface and decay with height within the troposphere.[11]

### Eye and center

![File:HurrArthur720p.webm](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/HurrArthur720p.webm/220px
--HurrArthur720p.webm.jpg)[Play
media](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6b/HurrArthur720p.webm "Play
media")

[](/wiki/File:HurrArthur720p.webm "Enlarge")

NASA animation of Hurricane Arthur in 2014 showing rain rates and internal
structure from [GPM](/wiki/Global_Precipitation_Measurement "Global
Precipitation Measurement") satellite data

At the center of a mature tropical cyclone, air sinks rather than rises. For a
sufficiently strong storm, air may sink over a layer deep enough to suppress
cloud formation, thereby creating a clear “[eye](/wiki/Eye_\(cyclone\) "Eye
\(cyclone\)")”. Weather in the eye is normally calm and free of clouds,
although the sea may be extremely violent.[12] The eye is normally circular in
shape, and is typically 30–65 km (19–40 mi) in diameter, though eyes as small
as 3 km (1.9 mi) and as large as 370 km (230 mi) have been observed.[13][14]

The cloudy outer edge of the eye is called the
“[eyewall](/wiki/Eye_\(cyclone\) "Eye \(cyclone\)")”. The eyewall typically
expands outward with height, resembling an arena football stadium; this
phenomenon is sometimes referred to as the _[stadium
effect](/wiki/Eye_\(cyclone\)#Stadium_effect "Eye \(cyclone\)")_.[14] The
[eyewall](/wiki/Eyewall "Eyewall") is where the greatest wind speeds are
found, air rises most rapidly, clouds reach to their highest altitude, and
precipitation is the heaviest. The heaviest wind damage occurs where a
tropical cyclone's eyewall passes over land.[12]

In a weaker storm, the eye may be obscured by the [central dense
overcast](/wiki/Central_dense_overcast "Central dense overcast"), which is the
upper-level cirrus shield that is associated with a concentrated area of
strong thunderstorm activity near the center of a tropical cyclone.[15]

The eyewall may vary over time in the form of [eyewall replacement
cycles](/wiki/Eye_\(cyclone\)#Eyewall_replacement_cycles "Eye \(cyclone\)"),
particularly in intense tropical cyclones. [Outer rainbands](/wiki/Rainbands
"Rainbands") can organize into an outer ring of thunderstorms that slowly
moves inward, which is believed to rob the primary eyewall of moisture and
[angular momentum](/wiki/Angular_momentum "Angular momentum"). When the
primary eyewall weakens, the tropical cyclone weakens temporarily. The outer
eyewall eventually replaces the primary one at the end of the cycle, at which
time the storm may return to its original intensity.[16]

### Rapid deepening

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Typhooon_Nabi_as_seen_from_the_ISS.jpg/220px-
Typhooon_Nabi_as_seen_from_the_ISS.jpg)](/wiki/File:Typhooon_Nabi_as_seen_from_the_ISS.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Typhooon_Nabi_as_seen_from_the_ISS.jpg "Enlarge")

[Typhoon Nabi](/wiki/Typhoon_Nabi "Typhoon Nabi") as seen from the
[International Space Station](/wiki/International_Space_Station "International
Space Station"), on September 3, 2005.

Main article: [Rapid deepening](/wiki/Rapid_deepening "Rapid deepening")

On occasion, tropical cyclones may undergo a process known as rapid deepening,
a period in which the minimum sea-level pressure of a tropical cyclone
decreases by 42mb in a 24-hour period.[17] In order for rapid deepening to
occur, several conditions must be in place. [Water
temperatures](/wiki/Sea_surface_temperature "Sea surface temperature") must be
extremely high (near or above 30 °C, 86 °F), and water of this temperature
must be sufficiently deep such that waves do not upwell cooler waters to the
surface. [Wind shear](/wiki/Wind_shear "Wind shear") must be low; when wind
shear is high, the [convection](/wiki/Convection#Atmospheric_convection
"Convection") and circulation in the cyclone will be disrupted. Usually, an
[anticyclone](/wiki/Anticyclone "Anticyclone") in the upper layers of the
[troposphere](/wiki/Troposphere "Troposphere") above the storm must be present
as well—for extremely low surface pressures to develop, air must be rising
very rapidly in the [eyewall](/wiki/Eye_\(cyclone\) "Eye \(cyclone\)") of the
storm, and an upper-level anticyclone helps channel this air away from the
cyclone efficiently.[18]

### Size

Size descriptions of tropical cyclones  
---  
ROCI | Type  
Less than 2 degrees latitude | Very small/midget  
2 to 3 degrees of latitude | Small  
3 to 6 degrees of latitude | Medium/Average  
6 to 8 degrees of latitude | Large  
Over 8 degrees of latitude | Very large[19]  
  
There are a variety of metrics commonly used to measure storm size. The most
common metrics include the radius of maximum wind, the radius of 34-knot wind
(i.e. [gale force](/wiki/Gale "Gale")), the radius of outermost closed
[isobar](/wiki/Isobar_\(meteorology\) "Isobar \(meteorology\)")
([ROCI](/wiki/Radius_of_outermost_closed_isobar "Radius of outermost closed
isobar")), and the radius of vanishing wind.[20][21] An additional metric is
the radius at which the cyclone's relative [vorticity](/wiki/Vorticity
"Vorticity") field decreases to 1×10−5 s−1.[14]

On Earth, tropical cyclones span a large range of sizes, from 100–2,000
kilometres (62–1,243 mi) as measured by the radius of vanishing wind. They are
largest on average in the northwest Pacific Ocean basin and smallest in the
northeastern Pacific Ocean basin.[22] If the radius of outermost closed isobar
is less than two [degrees of latitude](/wiki/Latitude "Latitude") (222 km (138
mi)), then the cyclone is "very small" or a "midget". A radius of 3–6 latitude
degrees (333–670 km (207–416 mi)) is considered "average sized". "Very large"
tropical cyclones have a radius of greater than 8 degrees (888 km (552
mi)).[19] Observations indicate that size is only weakly correlated to
variables such as storm intensity (i.e. maximum wind speed), radius of maximum
wind, latitude, and maximum potential intensity.[21][22]

Size plays an important role in modulating damage caused by a storm. All else
equal, a larger storm will impact a larger area for a longer period of time.
Additionally, a larger near-surface wind field can generate higher [storm
surge](/wiki/Storm_surge "Storm surge") due to the combination of longer wind
[fetch](/wiki/Fetch_\(geography\) "Fetch \(geography\)"), longer duration, and
enhanced [wave setup](/wiki/Wave_setup "Wave setup").[23]

The upper circulation of strong hurricanes extends into the
[tropopause](/wiki/Tropopause "Tropopause") of the atmosphere, which at low
latitudes is 15,000–18,000 metres (50,000–60,000 ft).[24]

## Physics and energetics

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Hurricane_profile.svg/250px-
Hurricane_profile.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Hurricane_profile.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Hurricane_profile.svg "Enlarge")

Tropical cyclones exhibit an overturning circulation where air inflows at low
levels near the surface, rises in thunderstorm clouds, and outflows at high
levels near the tropopause.[25]

The [three-dimensional](/wiki/Three-dimensional "Three-dimensional") wind
field in a tropical cyclone can be separated into two components: a "primary
circulation" and a "[secondary circulation](/wiki/Secondary_circulation
"Secondary circulation")". The primary circulation is the rotational part of
the flow; it is purely circular. The secondary circulation is the overturning
(in-up-out-down) part of the flow; it is in the
[radial](/wiki/Geometric_terms_of_location "Geometric terms of location") and
vertical directions. The primary circulation is larger in magnitude,
dominating the surface wind field, and is responsible for the majority of the
damage a storm causes, while the secondary circulation is slower but governs
the [energetics](/wiki/Energetics "Energetics") of the storm.

### Secondary circulation: a Carnot heat engine

A tropical cyclone's primary energy source is heat from the evaporation of
[water](/wiki/Water "Water") from the [ocean](/wiki/Ocean "Ocean") surface,
which ultimately [recondenses](/wiki/Condensation "Condensation") into clouds
and rain when the warm moist air rises and cools to
[saturation](/wiki/Saturated_fluid "Saturated fluid"). The energetics of the
system may be idealized as an atmospheric [Carnot heat
engine](/wiki/Carnot_heat_engine "Carnot heat engine").[26] First, inflowing
air near the surface acquires heat primarily via evaporation of water (i.e.
[latent heat](/wiki/Latent_heat "Latent heat")) at the temperature of the warm
ocean surface (during evaporation, the ocean cools and the air warms). Second,
the warmed air rises and cools within the eyewall while conserving total heat
content (latent heat is simply converted to [sensible
heat](/wiki/Sensible_heat "Sensible heat") during
[condensation](/wiki/Condensation "Condensation")). Third, air outflows and
loses heat via [infrared radiation](/wiki/Thermal_radiation "Thermal
radiation") to space at the temperature of the cold
[tropopause](/wiki/Tropopause "Tropopause"). Finally, air
[subsides](/wiki/Subsidence_\(atmosphere\) "Subsidence \(atmosphere\)") and
warms at the outer edge of the storm while conserving total heat content. The
first and third legs are nearly [isothermal](/wiki/Isothermal "Isothermal"),
while the second and fourth legs are nearly [isentropic](/wiki/Isentropic
"Isentropic"). This in-up-out-down overturning flow is known as the [secondary
circulation](/wiki/Secondary_flow "Secondary flow"). The Carnot perspective
provides an [upper bound](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone#Maximum_potential_intensity
"Tropical cyclone") on the maximum wind speed that a storm can attain.

Scientists estimate that a tropical cyclone releases heat energy at the rate
of 50 to 200 [exajoules](/wiki/Exajoule "Exajoule") (1018 J) per day,[27]
equivalent to about 1 PW (1015 watt). This rate of energy release is
equivalent to 70 times the [world energy
consumption](/wiki/World_energy_resources_and_consumption "World energy
resources and consumption") of humans and 200 times the worldwide electrical
generating capacity, or to exploding a 10-[megaton](/wiki/TNT_equivalent "TNT
equivalent") [nuclear bomb](/wiki/Nuclear_bomb "Nuclear bomb") every 20
minutes.[27][28]

### Primary circulation: rotating winds

The primary rotating flow in a tropical cyclone results from the [conservation
of angular momentum](/wiki/Conservation_of_angular_momentum "Conservation of
angular momentum") by the secondary circulation. [Absolute angular
momentum](/wiki/Absolute_angular_momentum "Absolute angular momentum") on a
rotating planet  M {\displaystyle M}
![M](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f82cade9898ced02fdd08712e5f0c0151758a0dd)
is given by

     M = 1 2 f r 2 + v r {\displaystyle M={\frac {1}{2}}fr^{2}+vr} ![M = \\frac{1}{2}fr^2 + vr](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e745754a2255a0214ba8f79b212758289099d639)

where  f {\displaystyle f}
![f](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/132e57acb643253e7810ee9702d9581f159a1c61)
is the [Coriolis parameter](/wiki/Coriolis_parameter "Coriolis parameter"),  v
{\displaystyle v}
![v](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e07b00e7fc0847fbd16391c778d65bc25c452597)
is the azimuthal (i.e. rotating) wind speed, and  r {\displaystyle r}
![r](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0d1ecb613aa2984f0576f70f86650b7c2a132538)
is the radius to the axis of rotation. The first term on the right hand side
is the component of planetary angular momentum that projects onto the local
vertical (i.e. the axis of rotation). The second term on the right hand side
is the relative angular momentum of the circulation itself with respect to the
axis of rotation. Because the planetary angular momentum term vanishes at the
equator (where  f = 0 {\displaystyle f=0}
![f=0](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1ee0fdf0f50fcba5afe3e856fcc7dc6acfa61014)
), tropical cyclones rarely [form](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone#Formation "Tropical
cyclone") within 5° of the equator.[6][29]

As air flows radially inward at low levels, it begins to rotate cyclonically
in order to conserve angular momentum. Similarly, as rapidly rotating air
flows radially outward near the tropopause, its cyclonic rotation decreases
and ultimately changes sign at large enough radius, resulting in an upper-
level [anti-cyclone](/wiki/Anti-cyclone "Anti-cyclone"). The result is a
vertical structure characterized by a strong [cyclone](/wiki/Cyclone
"Cyclone") at low levels and a strong [anti-cyclone](/wiki/Anti-cyclone "Anti-
cyclone") near the [tropopause](/wiki/Tropopause "Tropopause"); from [thermal
wind balance](/wiki/Thermal_wind "Thermal wind"), this corresponds to a system
that is warmer at its center than in the surrounding environment at all
altitudes (i.e. “warm-core”). From [hydrostatic
balance](/wiki/Hydrostatic_balance "Hydrostatic balance"), the warm core
translates to lower pressure at the center at all altitudes, with the maximum
pressure drop located at the surface.[11]

### Maximum potential intensity

Due to surface friction, the inflow only partially conserves angular momentum.
Thus, the sea surface lower boundary acts as both a source (evaporation) and
sink (friction) of energy for the system. This fact leads to the existence of
a theoretical upper bound on the strongest wind speed that a tropical cyclone
can attain. Because evaporation increases linearly with wind speed (just as
climbing out of a pool feels much colder on a windy day), there is a positive
feedback on energy input into the system known as the Wind-Induced Surface
Heat Exchange (WISHE) feedback.[26] This feedback is offset when frictional
dissipation, which increases with the cube of the wind speed, becomes
sufficiently large. This upper bound is called the “maximum potential
intensity”,  v p {\displaystyle v_{p}}
![v_p](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/537e72b1a70774ae976de89f7919dc0e0a9bb86d),
and is given by

     v p 2 = C k C d T s − T o T o Δ k {\displaystyle v_{p}^{2}={\frac {C_{k}}{C_{d}}}{\frac {T_{s}-T_{o}}{T_{o}}}\Delta k} ![v_p^2 = \\frac{C_k}{C_d}\\frac{T_s - T_o}{T_o}\\Delta k](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a7fb2f6e26d612beb99143358c734c6970bdf8d4)

where  T s {\displaystyle T_{s}}
![T_{s}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/942b5ac7697c72b9e3bc1e3b340daf7189fdf61f)
is the temperature of the sea surface,  T o {\displaystyle T_{o}}
![T_{o}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2991f18ef81fec2f94e3a532df91a079f3f6697d)
is the temperature of the outflow ([K]),  Δ k {\displaystyle \Delta k}
![\\Delta
k](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3f4119f8a26ff6ff37ca2d302fc36bf91334ec5c)
is the enthalpy difference between the surface and the overlying air ([J/kg]),
and  C k {\displaystyle C_{k}}
![C_{k}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1a0887b56787ba96e79de2b9f5c6ff30aabad1c6)
and  C d {\displaystyle C_{d}}
![C_{d}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d638b409d293db1874a1503bd0f87d20b3d57ed7)
are the surface [exchange coefficients](/wiki/Heat_transfer_coefficient "Heat
transfer coefficient") ([dimensionless](/wiki/Dimensionless "Dimensionless"))
of enthalpy and momentum, respectively.[30] The surface-air enthalpy
difference is taken as  Δ k = k s ∗ − k {\displaystyle \Delta k=k_{s}^{*}-k}
![\\Delta k =
k^*_s-k](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9089989e80b0a50c6c382db270b231c5ed25b91b),
where  k s ∗ {\displaystyle k_{s}^{*}}
![k^*_s](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7532aba5f600a7c3241dfe638f5874a41ce40ed5)
is the saturation [enthalpy](/wiki/Enthalpy "Enthalpy") of air at sea surface
temperature and sea-level pressure and  k {\displaystyle k}
![k](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c3c9a2c7b599b37105512c5d570edc034056dd40)
is the enthalpy of boundary layer air overlying the surface.

The maximum potential intensity is predominantly a function of the background
environment alone (i.e. without a tropical cyclone), and thus this quantity
can be used to determine which regions on Earth can support tropical cyclones
of a given intensity, and how these regions may evolve in time.[31][32]
Specifically, the maximum potential intensity has three components, but its
[variability in space and
time](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone#Characteristic_values_and_variability_on_Earth
"Tropical cyclone") is due predominantly to the variability in the surface-air
enthalpy difference component  Δ k {\displaystyle \Delta k} ![\\Delta
k](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3f4119f8a26ff6ff37ca2d302fc36bf91334ec5c).

#### Derivation

A tropical cyclone may be viewed as a [heat engine](/wiki/Heat_engine "Heat
engine") that converts input [heat](/wiki/Heat "Heat") energy from the surface
into [mechanical energy](/wiki/Mechanical_energy "Mechanical energy") that can
be used to do [mechanical work](/wiki/Mechanical_work "Mechanical work")
against surface friction. At equilibrium, the rate of net energy production in
the system must equal the rate of energy loss due to frictional dissipation at
the surface, i.e.

     W i n = W o u t {\displaystyle W_{in}=W_{out}} ![W_{in} = W_{out}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c6f53455e8968a96b21c527503bcdbd7366eea31)

The rate of energy loss per unit surface area from surface friction,  W o u t
{\displaystyle W_{out}}
![W_{out}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0b268f9b2a16d3e3e32de585eb140111f92f71fc),
is given by

     W o u t = C d ρ | u | 3 {\displaystyle W_{out}=C_{d}\rho |\mathbf {u} |^{3}} ![W_{out} = C_d \\rho |\\mathbf{u}|^3](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/dbd3241dd960eee8b8992758ac5ea5a38b0b1015)

where  ρ {\displaystyle \rho } ![\\rho ](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1f7d439671d1289b6a816e6af7a304be40608d64) is the density of near-surface air ([kg/m3]) and  | u | {\displaystyle |\mathbf {u} |} ![|\\mathbf{u}|](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/46a5525a5c8a36ca867220e6bba3938afd0872d2) is the near surface wind speed ([m/s]).

The rate of energy production per unit surface area,  W i n {\displaystyle
W_{in}}
![W_{in}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/8536dfcf0c76b87884d1a6e1e798e40c8c8916f7)
is given by

     W i n = ϵ Q i n {\displaystyle W_{in}=\epsilon Q_{in}} ![W_{in} = \\epsilon Q_{in}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/8269d3ba2249c863c010dead885ff99e121c9db6)

where  ϵ {\displaystyle \epsilon } ![\\epsilon
](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c3837cad72483d97bcdde49c85d3b7b859fb3fd2)
is the heat engine efficiency and  Q i n {\displaystyle Q_{in}}
![Q_{in}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/515dc23886db2c8ddb69a53b3aebef426872c1cb)
is the total rate of heat input into the system per unit surface area. Given
that a tropical cyclone may be idealized as a [Carnot heat
engine](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone#Secondary_circulation:_a_Carnot_heat_engine
"Tropical cyclone"), the Carnot heat engine efficiency is given by

     ϵ = T s − T o T s {\displaystyle \epsilon ={\frac {T_{s}-T_{o}}{T_{s}}}} ![\\epsilon = \\frac{T_s-T_o}{T_s}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3d13070a354bd41817899af53295c2ab101623db)

Heat (enthalpy) per unit mass is given by

     k = C p T + L v q {\displaystyle k=C_{p}T+L_{v}q} ![k = C_pT + L_vq](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ae53f584c21e8b2c909b2df0a1921e81c460e77a)

where  C p {\displaystyle C_{p}}
![C_{p}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/6bc37470431fbf62081b69ba870ad3f855178361)
is the heat capacity of air,  T {\displaystyle T}
![T](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ec7200acd984a1d3a3d7dc455e262fbe54f7f6e0)
is air temperature,  L v {\displaystyle L_{v}}
![L_{v}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/67d3252ec5dbd18467fc109498966e5abb43123b)
is the latent heat of vaporization, and  q {\displaystyle q}
![q](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/06809d64fa7c817ffc7e323f85997f783dbdf71d)
is the concentration of water vapor. The first component corresponds to
[sensible heat](/wiki/Sensible_heat "Sensible heat") and the second to [latent
heat](/wiki/Latent_heat "Latent heat").

There are two sources of heat input. The dominant source is the input of heat
at the surface, primarily due to evaporation. The bulk aerodynamic formula for
the rate of heat input per unit area at the surface,  Q i n : k {\displaystyle
Q_{in:k}}
![Q_{in:k}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0104639003b206dfdcd07a2c91a8c4f813fa46ec),
is given by

     Q i n : k = C k ρ | u | Δ k {\displaystyle Q_{in:k}=C_{k}\rho |\mathbf {u} |\Delta k} ![Q_{in:k} = C_k \\rho |\\mathbf{u}|\\Delta k](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/214a42f4bebfa205748de94a7fdddd82b275c24b)

where  Δ k = k s ∗ − k {\displaystyle \Delta k=k_{s}^{*}-k} ![\\Delta k =
k^*_s-k](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9089989e80b0a50c6c382db270b231c5ed25b91b)
represents the enthalpy difference between the ocean surface and the overlying
air. The second source is the internal sensible heat generated from frictional
dissipation (equal to  W o u t {\displaystyle W_{out}}
![W_{out}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/0b268f9b2a16d3e3e32de585eb140111f92f71fc)),
which occurs near the surface within the tropical cyclone and is recycled to
the system.

     Q i n : f r i c t i o n = C d ρ | u | 3 {\displaystyle Q_{in:friction}=C_{d}\rho |\mathbf {u} |^{3}} ![Q_{in:friction} = C_d \\rho |\\mathbf{u}|^3](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2fe1dcdb61e7bfeee97809e85614892266902925)

Thus, the total rate of net energy production per unit surface area is given
by

     W i n = T s − T o T s ( C k ρ | u | Δ k + C d ρ | u | 3 ) {\displaystyle W_{in}={\frac {T_{s}-T_{o}}{T_{s}}}\left(C_{k}\rho |\mathbf {u} |\Delta k+C_{d}\rho |\mathbf {u} |^{3}\right)} ![W_{in} = \\frac{T_s-T_o}{T_s}\\left\(C_k \\rho |\\mathbf{u}|\\Delta k + C_d \\rho |\\mathbf{u}|^3\\right\)](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2362233e63692f12d6da7082ca7682bc376bf50e)

Setting  W i n = W o u t {\displaystyle W_{in}=W_{out}} ![W_{in} = W_{out}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c6f53455e8968a96b21c527503bcdbd7366eea31) and taking  | u | ≈ v {\displaystyle |\mathbf {u} |\approx v} ![|\\mathbf{u}| \\approx v](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/25851db8dca7bd27c6e09ff4a1824ffc3d87e4a7) (i.e. the rotational wind speed is dominant) leads to the solution for  v p {\displaystyle v_{p}} ![v_p](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/537e72b1a70774ae976de89f7919dc0e0a9bb86d) given above. This derivation assumes that total energy input and loss within the system can be approximated by their values at the radius of maximum wind. The inclusion of  Q i n : f r i c t i o n {\displaystyle Q_{in:friction}} ![Q_{in:friction}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9f86b3b4c47fe71666adb37279f71b3b5c64b460) acts to multiply the total heat input rate by the factor  T s T o {\displaystyle {\frac {T_{s}}{T_{o}}}} ![\\frac{T_s}{T_o}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b1ef1f391bd63bfb0962f7b1f4cc2161504a7fe8). Mathematically, this has the effect of replacing  T s {\displaystyle T_{s}} ![T_{s}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/942b5ac7697c72b9e3bc1e3b340daf7189fdf61f) with  T o {\displaystyle T_{o}} ![T_{o}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2991f18ef81fec2f94e3a532df91a079f3f6697d) in the denominator of the Carnot efficiency.

An alternative definition for the maximum potential intensity, which is
mathematically equivalent to the above formulation, is

     v p = T s T o C k C d ( C A P E s ∗ − C A P E b ) | m {\displaystyle v_{p}={\sqrt {{\frac {T_{s}}{T_{o}}}{\frac {C_{k}}{C_{d}}}(CAPE_{s}^{*}-CAPE_{b})|_{m}}}} ![v_p = \\sqrt{\\frac{T_s}{T_o}\\frac{C_k}{C_d}\(CAPE^*_s-CAPE_b\)|_m}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/862f63638626f581ec9d4267a2fa1270b740e2c5)

where CAPE stands for the [Convective Available Potential
Energy](/wiki/Convective_Available_Potential_Energy "Convective Available
Potential Energy"),  C A P E s ∗ {\displaystyle CAPE_{s}^{*}}
![CAPE^*_s](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/c99041728b162b79b419529273acff7516e119c7)
is the CAPE of an air parcel lifted from saturation at sea level in reference
to the environmental [sounding](/wiki/Atmospheric_sounding "Atmospheric
sounding"),  C A P E b {\displaystyle CAPE_{b}}
![CAPE_b](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/cbf0edc477551cc88e22167570fbf9851210c87f)
is the CAPE of the boundary layer air, and both quantities are calculated at
the radius of maximum wind.[33]

#### Characteristic values and variability on Earth

On Earth, a characteristic temperature for  T s {\displaystyle T_{s}}
![T_{s}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/942b5ac7697c72b9e3bc1e3b340daf7189fdf61f)
is 300 K and for  T o {\displaystyle T_{o}}
![T_{o}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/2991f18ef81fec2f94e3a532df91a079f3f6697d)
is 200 K, corresponding to a Carnot efficiency of  ϵ = 1 / 3 {\displaystyle
\epsilon =1/3} ![\\epsilon =
1/3](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/878465995e88d7bd374c9b9820ab20420fc7191b).
The ratio of the surface exchange coefficients,  C k / C d {\displaystyle
C_{k}/C_{d}}
![C_k/C_d](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/8b1c4c1e92fc95d5c4233588d3f4fb689a40c887),
is typically taken to be 1. However, observations suggest that the drag
coefficient  C d {\displaystyle C_{d}}
![C_{d}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/d638b409d293db1874a1503bd0f87d20b3d57ed7)
varies with wind speed and may decrease at high wind speeds within the
boundary layer of a mature hurricane.[34] Additionally,  C k {\displaystyle
C_{k}}
![C_{k}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1a0887b56787ba96e79de2b9f5c6ff30aabad1c6)
may vary at high wind speeds due to the effect of [sea spray](/wiki/Sea_spray
"Sea spray") on evaporation within the boundary layer.[35]

A characteristic value of the maximum potential intensity,  v p {\displaystyle
v_{p}}
![v_p](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/537e72b1a70774ae976de89f7919dc0e0a9bb86d),
is 80 metres per second (180 mph; 290 km/h). However, this quantity varies
significantly across space and time, particularly within the [seasonal
cycle](/wiki/Season "Season"), spanning a range of 0 to 100 metres per second
(0 to 224 mph; 0 to 360 km/h).[33] This variability is primarily due to
variability in the surface enthalpy disequilibrium (  Δ k {\displaystyle
\Delta k} ![\\Delta
k](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/3f4119f8a26ff6ff37ca2d302fc36bf91334ec5c)
) as well as in the thermodynamic structure of the troposphere, which are
controlled by the large-scale dynamics of the tropical climate. These
processes are modulated by factors including the sea surface temperature (and
underlying ocean dynamics), background near-surface wind speed, and the
vertical structure of atmospheric radiative heating.[36] The nature of this
modulation is complex, particularly on climate time-scales (decades or
longer). On shorter time-scales, variability in the maximum potential
intensity is commonly linked to sea surface temperature perturbations from the
tropical mean, as regions with relatively warm water have thermodynamic states
much more capable of sustaining a tropical cyclone than regions with
relatively cold water.[37] However, this relationship is indirect via the
large-scale dynamics of the tropics; the direct influence of the absolute sea
surface temperature on  v p {\displaystyle v_{p}}
![v_p](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/537e72b1a70774ae976de89f7919dc0e0a9bb86d)
is weak in comparison.

### Interaction with the upper ocean

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/GulfMexTemps_2005Hurricanes.gif/220px-
GulfMexTemps_2005Hurricanes.gif)](/wiki/File:GulfMexTemps_2005Hurricanes.gif)

[](/wiki/File:GulfMexTemps_2005Hurricanes.gif "Enlarge")

Chart displaying the drop in surface temperature in the [Gulf of
Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico") as Hurricanes
[Katrina](/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina "Hurricane Katrina") and
[Rita](/wiki/Hurricane_Rita "Hurricane Rita") passed over

The passage of a tropical cyclone over the ocean causes the upper layers of
the ocean to cool substantially, which can influence subsequent cyclone
development. This cooling is primarily caused by wind-driven mixing of cold
water from deeper in the ocean with the warm surface waters. This effect
results in a negative feedback process that can inhibit further development or
lead to weakening. Additional cooling may come in the form of cold water from
falling raindrops (this is because the atmosphere is cooler at higher
altitudes). Cloud cover may also play a role in cooling the ocean, by
shielding the ocean surface from direct sunlight before and slightly after the
storm passage. All these effects can combine to produce a dramatic drop in sea
surface temperature over a large area in just a few days.[38]

There are six [Regional Specialized Meteorological
Centers](/wiki/Regional_Specialized_Meteorological_Center "Regional
Specialized Meteorological Center") (RSMCs) worldwide. These organizations are
designated by the [World Meteorological
Organization](/wiki/World_Meteorological_Organization "World Meteorological
Organization") and are responsible for tracking and issuing bulletins,
warnings, and advisories about tropical cyclones in their designated areas of
responsibility. In addition, there are six [Tropical Cyclone Warning
Centers](/wiki/Tropical_Cyclone_Warning_Center "Tropical Cyclone Warning
Center") (TCWCs) that provide information to smaller regions.[44]

The RSMCs and TCWCs are not the only organizations that provide information
about tropical cyclones to the public. The [Joint Typhoon Warning
Center](/wiki/Joint_Typhoon_Warning_Center "Joint Typhoon Warning Center")
(JTWC) issues advisories in all basins except the Northern Atlantic for the
purposes of the [United States Government](/wiki/United_States_Government
"United States Government").[45] The [Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and
Astronomical Services
Administration](/wiki/Philippine_Atmospheric,_Geophysical_and_Astronomical_Services_Administration
"Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services
Administration") (PAGASA) issues advisories and names for tropical cyclones
that approach the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines") in the
Northwestern Pacific to protect the life and property of its citizens.[46] The
[Canadian Hurricane Center](/wiki/Canadian_Hurricane_Center "Canadian
Hurricane Center") (CHC) issues advisories on hurricanes and their remnants
for Canadian citizens when they affect Canada.[47]

On March 26, 2004, [Hurricane Catarina](/wiki/Hurricane_Catarina "Hurricane
Catarina") became the first recorded [South Atlantic
cyclone](/wiki/South_Atlantic_tropical_cyclone "South Atlantic tropical
cyclone"), striking southern [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil "Brazil") with winds
equivalent to Category 2 on the [Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale](/wiki/Saffir-
Simpson_Hurricane_Scale "Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale"). As the cyclone
formed outside the authority of another warning center, Brazilian
meteorologists initially treated the system as an [extratropical
cyclone](/wiki/Extratropical_cyclone "Extratropical cyclone"), but later on
classified it as tropical.[48]

## Formation

Main article: [Tropical cyclogenesis](/wiki/Tropical_cyclogenesis "Tropical
cyclogenesis")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Global_tropical_cyclone_tracks-
edit2.jpg/250px-Global_tropical_cyclone_tracks-
edit2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Global_tropical_cyclone_tracks-edit2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Global_tropical_cyclone_tracks-edit2.jpg "Enlarge")

the [International Date Line](/wiki/International_Date_Line "International
Date Line") sees more tropical cyclones than any other basin, while there is
almost no activity in the southern hemisphere between Africa and
[160˚W](/wiki/160th_meridian_west "160th meridian west").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Tropical_cyclones_1945_2006_wikicolor.png/250px-
Tropical_cyclones_1945_2006_wikicolor.png)](/wiki/File:Tropical_cyclones_1945_2006_wikicolor.png)

Map of all tropical cyclone tracks from 1945 to 2006. [Equal-area
projection](/wiki/Map_projection#Equal-area "Map projection").

Worldwide, tropical cyclone activity peaks in late summer, when the difference
between temperatures aloft and sea surface temperatures is the greatest.
However, each particular basin has its own seasonal patterns. On a worldwide
scale, May is the least active month, while September is the most active
month. November is the only month in which all the [tropical cyclone
basins](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone_basins "Tropical cyclone basins") are
active.[49]

### Times

In the Northern [Atlantic Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean"), a
distinct [cyclone season](/wiki/Atlantic_hurricane_season "Atlantic hurricane
season") occurs from June 1 to November 30, sharply peaking from late August
through September.[49] The statistical peak of the Atlantic hurricane season
is September 10. The Northeast [Pacific Ocean](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean "Pacific
Ocean") has a broader period of activity, but in a similar time frame to the
Atlantic.[50] The Northwest Pacific sees tropical cyclones year-round, with a
minimum in February and March and a peak in early September.[49] In the North
Indian basin, storms are most common from April to December, with peaks in May
and November.[49] In the Southern Hemisphere, the tropical cyclone year begins
on July 1 and runs all year-round encompassing the tropical cyclone seasons,
which run from November 1 until the end of April, with peaks in mid-February
to early March.[49][51]

### Factors

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Atlantic_hurricane_graphic.png/250px-
Atlantic_hurricane_graphic.png)](/wiki/File:Atlantic_hurricane_graphic.png)

[](/wiki/File:Atlantic_hurricane_graphic.png "Enlarge")

Waves in the trade winds in the Atlantic Ocean—areas of converging winds that
move along the same track as the prevailing wind—create instabilities in the
atmosphere that may lead to the formation of hurricanes.

The formation of tropical cyclones is the topic of extensive ongoing research
and is still not fully understood.[55] While six factors appear to be
generally necessary, tropical cyclones may occasionally form without meeting
all of the following conditions. In most situations, [water
temperatures](/wiki/Sea_surface_temperature "Sea surface temperature") of at
least 26.5 °C (79.7 °F) are needed down to a depth of at least 50 m (160
ft);[56] waters of this temperature cause the overlying atmosphere to be
unstable enough to sustain convection and thunderstorms.[57] For tropical
transitioning cyclones (i.e. [Hurricane Ophelia
(2017)](/wiki/Hurricane_Ophelia_\(2017\) "Hurricane Ophelia \(2017\)")) a
water temperature of at least 22.5 °C (72.5 °F) has been suggested.[58]

Another factor is rapid cooling with height, which allows the release of the
[heat of condensation](/wiki/Heat_of_condensation "Heat of condensation") that
powers a tropical cyclone.[56] High humidity is needed, especially in the
lower-to-mid [troposphere](/wiki/Troposphere "Troposphere"); when there is a
great deal of moisture in the atmosphere, conditions are more favorable for
disturbances to develop.[56] Low amounts of [wind shear](/wiki/Wind_shear
"Wind shear") are needed, as high shear is disruptive to the storm's
circulation.[56] Tropical cyclones generally need to form more than 555 km
(345 mi) or five degrees of latitude away from the [equator](/wiki/Equator
"Equator"), allowing the [Coriolis effect](/wiki/Coriolis_effect "Coriolis
effect") to deflect winds blowing towards the low pressure center and creating
a circulation.[56] Lastly, a formative tropical cyclone needs a preexisting
system of disturbed weather. Tropical cyclones will not form
spontaneously.[56] Low-latitude and low-level westerly wind bursts associated
with the [Madden-Julian oscillation](/wiki/Madden-Julian_oscillation "Madden-
Julian oscillation") can create favorable conditions for tropical cyclogenesis
by initiating tropical disturbances.[59]

### Locations

Most tropical cyclones form in a worldwide band of thunderstorm activity near
the [equator](/wiki/Equator "Equator"), referred to as the Intertropical Front
(ITF), the [Intertropical Convergence
Zone](/wiki/Intertropical_Convergence_Zone "Intertropical Convergence Zone")
(ITCZ), or the [monsoon trough](/wiki/Monsoon_trough "Monsoon
trough").[60][61][62] Another important source of atmospheric instability is
found in [tropical waves](/wiki/Tropical_wave "Tropical wave"), which
contribute to the development of about 85% of intense tropical cyclones in the
Atlantic Ocean and become most of the tropical cyclones in the Eastern
Pacific.[63][64][65] The majority forms between 10 and 30 degrees of latitude
away of the equator,[66] and 87% forms no farther away than 20 degrees north
or south.[67][68] Because the Coriolis effect initiates and maintains their
rotation, tropical cyclones rarely form or move within 5 degrees of the
equator, where the effect is weakest.[67] However, it is still possible for
tropical systems to form within this boundary as [Tropical Storm
Vamei](/wiki/Tropical_Storm_Vamei "Tropical Storm Vamei") and [Cyclone
Agni](/wiki/Cyclone_Agni "Cyclone Agni") did in 2001 and 2004,
respectively.[69][70]

## Movement

The movement of a tropical cyclone (i.e. its "track") is typically
approximated as the sum of two terms: "steering" by the background
environmental wind and "beta drift".[71]

### Environmental steering

Environmental steering is the dominant term. Conceptually, it represents the
movement of the storm due to prevailing winds and other wider environmental
conditions, similar to "leaves carried along by a stream".[72] Physically, the
winds, or [flow field](/w/index.php?title=Flow_field&action=edit&redlink=1
"Flow field \(page does not exist\)"), in the vicinity of a tropical cyclone
may be treated as having two parts: the flow associated with the storm itself,
and the large-scale background flow of the environment in which the storm
takes place. In this way, tropical cyclone motion may be represented to first-
order simply as [advection](/wiki/Advection "Advection") of the storm by the
local environmental flow. This environmental flow is termed the "steering
flow".

Climatologically, tropical cyclones are steered primarily westward by the
east-to-west [trade winds](/wiki/Trade_winds "Trade winds") on the equatorial
side of the [subtropical ridge](/wiki/Subtropical_ridge "Subtropical ridge")—a
persistent high-pressure area over the world's subtropical oceans.[72] In the
tropical North Atlantic and Northeast Pacific oceans, the trade winds steer
[tropical easterly waves](/wiki/Tropical_wave "Tropical wave") westward from
the African coast toward the Caribbean Sea, North America, and ultimately into
the central Pacific Ocean before the waves dampen out.[64] These waves are the
precursors to many tropical cyclones within this region.[63] In contrast, in
the [Indian Ocean](/wiki/Indian_Ocean "Indian Ocean") and Western Pacific in
both hemispheres, tropical cyclogenesis is influenced less by tropical
easterly waves and more by the seasonal movement of the Inter-tropical
Convergence Zone and the monsoon trough.[73] Additionally, tropical cyclone
motion can be influenced by transient weather systems, such as extratropical
cyclones.

### Beta drift

In addition to environmental steering, a tropical cyclone will tend to drift
slowly poleward and westward, a motion known as "beta drift". This motion is
due to the superposition of a vortex, such as a tropical cyclone, onto an
environment in which the [Coriolis force](/wiki/Coriolis_force "Coriolis
force") varies with latitude, such as on a sphere or [beta
plane](/wiki/Beta_plane "Beta plane"). It is induced indirectly by the storm
itself, the result of a feedback between the cyclonic flow of the storm and
its environment.

Physically, the cyclonic circulation of the storm advects environmental air
poleward east of center and equatorial west of center. Because air must
conserve its [angular momentum](/wiki/Absolute_angular_momentum "Absolute
angular momentum"), this flow configuration induces a cyclonic gyre
equatorward and westward of the storm center and an anticyclonic gyre poleward
and eastward of the storm center. The combined flow of these gyres acts to
advect the storm slowly poleward and westward. This effect occurs even if
there is zero environmental flow.

### Multiple storm interaction

Main article: [Fujiwhara effect](/wiki/Fujiwhara_effect "Fujiwhara effect")

A third component of motion that occurs relatively infrequently involves the
interaction of multiple tropical cyclones. When two cyclones approach one
another, their centers will begin orbiting cyclonically about a point between
the two systems. Depending on their separation distance and strength, the two
vortices may simply orbit around one another or else may spiral into the
center point and merge. When the two vortices are of unequal size, the larger
vortex will tend to dominate the interaction, and the smaller vortex will
orbit around it. This phenomenon is called the Fujiwhara effect, after
[Sakuhei Fujiwhara](/wiki/Sakuhei_Fujiwhara "Sakuhei Fujiwhara").[74]

### Interaction with the mid-latitude westerlies

See also: [Westerlies](/wiki/Westerlies "Westerlies")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Ioke_2006_track.png/250px-
Ioke_2006_track.png)](/wiki/File:Ioke_2006_track.png)

[](/wiki/File:Ioke_2006_track.png "Enlarge")

Storm track of [Typhoon Ioke](/wiki/Hurricane_Ioke "Hurricane Ioke"), showing
recurvature off the Japanese coast in
[2006](/wiki/2006_Pacific_hurricane_season "2006 Pacific hurricane season")

Though a tropical cyclone typically moves from east to west in the tropics,
its track may shift poleward and eastward either as it moves west of the
subtropical ridge axis or else if it interacts with the mid-latitude flow,
such as the [jet stream](/wiki/Jet_stream "Jet stream") or an [extratropical
cyclone](/wiki/Extratropical_cyclone "Extratropical cyclone"). This motion,
termed "recurvature", commonly occurs near the western edge of the major ocean
basins, where the jet stream typically has a poleward component and
extratropical cyclones are common.[75] An example of tropical cyclone
recurvature was [Typhoon Ioke](/wiki/Hurricane_Ioke "Hurricane Ioke") in
2006.[76]

### Landfall

See also: [Tropical cyclogenesis § Unusual areas of
formation](/wiki/Tropical_cyclogenesis#Unusual_areas_of_formation "Tropical
cyclogenesis")

The landfall of a tropical cyclone occurs when a storm's surface center moves
over a coastline.[9] Storm conditions may be experienced on the coast and
inland hours before landfall; in fact, a tropical cyclone can launch its
strongest winds over land, yet not make landfall. NOAA uses the term "direct
hit" to describe when a location (on the left side of the eye) falls within
the radius of maximum winds (or twice that radius if on the right side),
whether or not the hurricane's eye made landfall.[9]

## Dissipation

### Factors

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/TropicalStormFranklin05.jpg/250px-
TropicalStormFranklin05.jpg)](/wiki/File:TropicalStormFranklin05.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:TropicalStormFranklin05.jpg "Enlarge")

[Tropical Storm Franklin](/wiki/Tropical_Storm_Franklin_\(2005\) "Tropical
Storm Franklin \(2005\)"), an example of a strongly [sheared](/wiki/Windshear
"Windshear") tropical cyclone in the [North Atlantic
hurricane](/wiki/North_Atlantic_hurricane "North Atlantic hurricane") basin
during [2005](/wiki/2005_Atlantic_hurricane_season "2005 Atlantic hurricane
season")

A tropical cyclone can cease to have tropical characteristics in several
different ways. One such way is if it moves over land, thus depriving it of
the warm water it needs to power itself, quickly losing strength.[77] Most
strong storms lose their strength very rapidly after landfall and become
disorganized areas of low pressure within a day or two, or evolve into
extratropical cyclones. There is a chance a tropical cyclone could regenerate
if it managed to get back over open warm water, such as with [Hurricane
Ivan](/wiki/Hurricane_Ivan "Hurricane Ivan"). If it remains over mountains for
even a short time, weakening will accelerate.[78] Many storm fatalities occur
in mountainous terrain, when diminishing cyclones unleash their moisture as
torrential rainfall.[79] This rainfall may lead to deadly floods and
mudslides, as was the case with [Hurricane Mitch](/wiki/Hurricane_Mitch
"Hurricane Mitch") around Honduras in October 1998.[80] Without warm surface
water, the storm cannot survive.[81]

A tropical cyclone can dissipate when it moves over waters significantly below
26.5 °C (79.7 °F). This will cause the storm to lose its tropical
characteristics, such as a warm core with thunderstorms near the center, and
become a remnant [low-pressure area](/wiki/Low-pressure_area "Low-pressure
area"). These remnant systems may persist for up to several days before losing
their identity. This dissipation mechanism is most common in the eastern North
Pacific.[82] Weakening or dissipation can occur if it experiences vertical
wind shear, causing the convection and heat engine to move away from the
center; this normally ceases development of a tropical cyclone.[83] In
addition, its interaction with the main belt of the Westerlies, by means of
merging with a nearby frontal zone, can cause tropical cyclones to evolve into
[extratropical cyclones](/wiki/Extratropical_cyclones "Extratropical
cyclones"). This transition can take 1–3 days.[84] Even after a tropical
cyclone is said to be extratropical or dissipated, it can still have tropical
storm force (or occasionally hurricane/typhoon force) winds and drop several
inches of rainfall. In the [Pacific Ocean](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean "Pacific
Ocean") and [Atlantic Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean"), such
tropical-derived cyclones of higher latitudes can be violent and may
occasionally remain at hurricane or typhoon-force wind speeds when they reach
the west coast of North America. These phenomena can also affect Europe, where
they are known as _[European windstorms](/wiki/European_windstorm "European
windstorm")_ ; [Hurricane Iris's](/wiki/Hurricane_Iris_\(1995\) "Hurricane
Iris \(1995\)") extratropical remnants are an example of such a windstorm from
1995.[85] A cyclone can also merge with another area of low pressure, becoming
a larger area of low pressure. This can strengthen the resultant system,
although it may no longer be a tropical cyclone.[83] Studies in the 2000s have
given rise to the hypothesis that large amounts of dust reduce the strength of
tropical cyclones.[86]

### Artificial dissipation

In the 1960s and 1970s, the [United States
government](/wiki/United_States_government "United States government")
attempted to weaken hurricanes through [Project
Stormfury](/wiki/Project_Stormfury "Project Stormfury") by
[seeding](/wiki/Cloud_seeding "Cloud seeding") selected storms with [silver
iodide](/wiki/Silver_iodide "Silver iodide"). It was thought that the seeding
would cause [supercooled water](/wiki/Supercooled_water "Supercooled water")
in the outer rainbands to freeze, causing the inner eyewall to collapse and
thus reducing the winds.[87] The winds of [Hurricane
Debbie](/wiki/Hurricane_Debbie_\(1969\) "Hurricane Debbie \(1969\)")—a
hurricane seeded in Project Stormfury—dropped as much as 31%, but Debbie
regained its strength after each of two seeding forays.[88] In an earlier
episode in 1947, disaster struck when a hurricane east of [Jacksonville,
Florida](/wiki/Jacksonville,_Florida "Jacksonville, Florida") promptly changed
its course after being seeded, and smashed into [Savannah,
Georgia](/wiki/Savannah,_Georgia "Savannah, Georgia").[89] Because there was
so much uncertainty about the behavior of these storms, the federal government
would not approve seeding operations unless the hurricane had a less than 10%
chance of making landfall within 48 hours, greatly reducing the number of
possible test storms. The project was dropped after it was discovered that
[eyewall replacement cycles](/wiki/Eyewall_replacement_cycle "Eyewall
replacement cycle") occur naturally in strong hurricanes, casting doubt on the
result of the earlier attempts. Today, it is known that silver iodide seeding
is not likely to have an effect because the amount of supercooled water in the
rainbands of a tropical cyclone is too low.[90]

Other approaches have been suggested over time, including cooling the water
under a tropical cyclone by towing [icebergs](/wiki/Iceberg "Iceberg") into
the tropical oceans.[91] Other ideas range from covering the ocean in a
substance that inhibits evaporation,[92] dropping large quantities of ice into
the eye at very early stages of development (so that the [latent
heat](/wiki/Heat_of_condensation "Heat of condensation") is absorbed by the
ice, instead of being converted to kinetic energy that would feed the positive
feedback loop),[91] or blasting the cyclone apart with nuclear weapons.[93]
Project Cirrus even involved throwing dry ice on a cyclone.[94] These
approaches all suffer from one flaw above many others: tropical cyclones are
simply too large and short-lived for any of the weakening techniques to be
practical.[95]

## Effects

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Hurricane_katrina_damage_gulfport_mississippi.jpg/250px-
Hurricane_katrina_damage_gulfport_mississippi.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hurricane_katrina_damage_gulfport_mississippi.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hurricane_katrina_damage_gulfport_mississippi.jpg "Enlarge")

The aftermath of [Hurricane Katrina](/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina "Hurricane
Katrina") in [Gulfport, Mississippi](/wiki/Gulfport,_Mississippi "Gulfport,
Mississippi").

Main article: [Effects of tropical
cyclones](/wiki/Effects_of_tropical_cyclones "Effects of tropical cyclones")

Tropical cyclones out at sea cause large waves, [heavy
rain](/wiki/Heavy_rain_\(meteorology\) "Heavy rain \(meteorology\)"),
[flood](/wiki/Flood "Flood") and high winds, disrupting international shipping
and, at times, causing shipwrecks.[96] Tropical cyclones stir up water,
leaving a cool wake behind them, which causes the region to be less favorable
for subsequent tropical cyclones.[38] On land, strong [winds](/wiki/Wind
"Wind") can damage or destroy vehicles, buildings, bridges, and other outside
objects, turning loose debris into deadly flying projectiles. The [storm
surge](/wiki/Storm_surge "Storm surge"), or the increase in sea level due to
the cyclone, is typically the worst effect from landfalling tropical cyclones,
historically resulting in 90% of tropical cyclone deaths.[97] The broad
rotation of a landfalling tropical cyclone, and vertical wind shear at its
periphery, spawns [tornadoes](/wiki/History_of_tropical_cyclone-
spawned_tornadoes "History of tropical cyclone-spawned tornadoes"). Tornadoes
can also be spawned as a result of [eyewall
mesovortices](/wiki/Eyewall_mesovortices "Eyewall mesovortices"), which
persist until landfall.[98]

Over the past two centuries, tropical cyclones have been responsible for the
deaths of about 1.9 million people worldwide. Large areas of standing water
caused by flooding lead to infection, as well as contributing to mosquito-
borne illnesses. Crowded evacuees in [shelters](/wiki/Emergency_shelter
"Emergency shelter") increase the risk of disease propagation.[97] Tropical
cyclones significantly interrupt infrastructure, leading to power outages,
bridge destruction, and the hampering of reconstruction efforts.[97][99] On
average, the Gulf and east coasts of the United States suffer approximately US
$5 billion (1995 US $) in cyclone damage every year. The majority (83%) of
tropical cyclone damage is caused by severe hurricanes, category 3 or greater.
However, category 3 or greater hurricanes only account for about one-fifth of
cyclones that make landfall every year.[100]

Although cyclones take an enormous toll in lives and personal property, they
may be important factors in the
[precipitation](/wiki/Precipitation_\(meteorology\) "Precipitation
\(meteorology\)") regimes of places they impact, as they may bring much-needed
precipitation to otherwise dry regions.[101] Tropical cyclones also help
maintain the global heat balance by moving warm, moist tropical air to the
[middle latitudes](/wiki/Middle_latitudes "Middle latitudes") and polar
regions,[102] and by regulating the [thermohaline
circulation](/wiki/Thermohaline_circulation "Thermohaline circulation")
through [upwelling](/wiki/Upwelling "Upwelling").[103] The storm surge and
winds of hurricanes may be destructive to human-made structures, but they also
stir up the waters of coastal [estuaries](/wiki/Estuary "Estuary"), which are
typically important fish breeding locales. Tropical cyclone destruction spurs
redevelopment, greatly increasing local property values.[104]

When hurricanes surge upon shore from the ocean, salt is introduced to many
freshwater areas and raises the [salinity](/wiki/Salinity "Salinity") levels
too high for some habitats to withstand. Some are able to cope with the salt
and recycle it back into the ocean, but others can not release the extra
surface water quickly enough or do not have a large enough freshwater source
to replace it. Because of this, some species of plants and vegetation die due
to the excess salt.[105] In addition, hurricanes can carry
[toxins](/wiki/Toxins "Toxins") and [acids](/wiki/Acids "Acids") onto shore
when they make landfall. The flood water can pick up the toxins from different
spills and contaminate the land that it passes over. The toxins are very
harmful to the people and animals in the area, as well as the environment
around them. The flooding water can also spark many dangerous oil spills.[106]

"Hurricane Hunter" \- WP-3D Orion is used to go into the eye of a hurricane
for data collection and measurements purposes.

Intense tropical cyclones pose a particular observation challenge, as they are
a dangerous oceanic phenomenon, and [weather stations](/wiki/Weather_station
"Weather station"), being relatively sparse, are rarely available on the site
of the storm itself. In general, surface observations are available only if
the storm is passing over an island or a coastal area, or if there is a nearby
ship. Real-time measurements are usually taken in the periphery of the
cyclone, where conditions are less catastrophic and its true strength cannot
be evaluated. For this reason, there are teams of meteorologists that move
into the path of tropical cyclones to help evaluate their strength at the
point of landfall.[107]

Tropical cyclones far from land are tracked by [weather
satellites](/wiki/Weather_satellite "Weather satellite") capturing
[visible](/wiki/Visible_light "Visible light") and [infrared](/wiki/Infrared
"Infrared") images from space, usually at half-hour to quarter-hour intervals.
As a storm approaches land, it can be observed by land-based
[Doppler](/wiki/Pulse-Doppler_radar "Pulse-Doppler radar") [weather
radar](/wiki/Weather_radar "Weather radar"). Radar plays a crucial role around
landfall by showing a storm's location and intensity every several
minutes.[108]

[In situ](/wiki/In_situ "In situ") measurements, in real-time, can be taken by
sending specially equipped reconnaissance flights into the cyclone. In the
Atlantic basin, these flights are regularly flown by United States government
[hurricane hunters](/wiki/Hurricane_hunters "Hurricane hunters").[109] The
aircraft used are [WC-130](/wiki/WC-130 "WC-130") Hercules and
[WP-3D](/wiki/WP-3D "WP-3D") Orions, both four-engine
[turboprop](/wiki/Turboprop "Turboprop") cargo aircraft. These aircraft fly
directly into the cyclone and take direct and remote-sensing measurements. The
aircraft also launch [GPS dropsondes](/wiki/GPS_dropsonde "GPS dropsonde")
inside the cyclone. These sondes measure temperature, humidity, pressure, and
especially winds between flight level and the ocean's surface. A new era in
hurricane observation began when a remotely piloted
[Aerosonde](/wiki/Insitu_Aerosonde "Insitu Aerosonde"), a small drone
aircraft, was flown through Tropical Storm Ophelia as it passed Virginia's
Eastern Shore during the 2005 hurricane season. A similar mission was also
completed successfully in the western Pacific Ocean. This demonstrated a new
way to probe the storms at low altitudes that human pilots seldom dare.[110]

### Forecasting

See also: [Tropical cyclone track
forecasting](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone_track_forecasting "Tropical cyclone track
forecasting"), [Tropical cyclone prediction
model](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone_prediction_model "Tropical cyclone prediction
model"), and [Tropical cyclone rainfall
forecasting](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone_rainfall_forecasting "Tropical cyclone
rainfall forecasting")

Because of the forces that affect tropical cyclone tracks, accurate track
predictions depend on determining the position and strength of high- and low-
pressure areas, and predicting how those areas will change during the life of
a tropical system. The deep layer mean flow, or average wind through the depth
of the [troposphere](/wiki/Troposphere "Troposphere"), is considered the best
tool in determining track direction and speed. If storms are significantly
sheared, use of wind speed measurements at a lower altitude, such as at the 70
kPa pressure surface (3,000 metres or 9,800 feet above sea level) will produce
better predictions. Tropical forecasters also consider smoothing out short-
term [wobbles](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/wiggle "wikt:wiggle") of the
storm as it allows them to determine a more accurate long-term
trajectory.[111] High-speed computers and sophisticated simulation software
allow forecasters to produce [computer
models](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone_prediction_model "Tropical cyclone prediction
model") that predict tropical cyclone tracks based on the future position and
strength of high- and low-pressure systems. Combining forecast models with
increased understanding of the forces that act on tropical cyclones, as well
as with a wealth of data from Earth-orbiting [satellites](/wiki/Satellites
"Satellites") and other sensors, scientists have increased the accuracy of
track forecasts over recent decades.[112] However, scientists are not as
skillful at predicting the intensity of tropical cyclones.[113] The lack of
improvement in intensity forecasting is attributed to the complexity of
tropical systems and an incomplete understanding of factors that affect their
development. New tropical cyclone position and forecast information is
available at least every twelve hours in the Southern Hemisphere and at least
every six hours in the Northern Hemisphere from Regional Specialized
Meteorological Centers and Tropical Cyclone Warning
Centers.[44][114][115][116][117]

## Classifications, terminology, and naming

### Intensity classifications

Main article: [Tropical cyclone scales](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone_scales
"Tropical cyclone scales")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Typhoon_saomai_060807.jpg/250px-
Typhoon_saomai_060807.jpg)](/wiki/File:Typhoon_saomai_060807.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Typhoon_saomai_060807.jpg "Enlarge")

Three tropical cyclones of the [2006 Pacific typhoon
season](/wiki/2006_Pacific_typhoon_season "2006 Pacific typhoon season") at
different stages of development. The weakest (left) demonstrates only the most
basic circular shape. A stronger storm (top right) demonstrates [spiral
banding](/wiki/Rainbands "Rainbands") and increased centralization, while the
strongest (lower right) has developed an [eye](/wiki/Eye_\(cyclone\) "Eye
\(cyclone\)").

Tropical cyclones are classified into three main groups, based on intensity:
tropical depressions, tropical storms, and a third group of more intense
storms, whose name depends on the region. For example, if a tropical storm in
the Northwestern Pacific reaches hurricane-strength winds on the [Beaufort
scale](/wiki/Beaufort_scale "Beaufort scale"), it is referred to as a
_typhoon_ ; if a tropical storm passes the same benchmark in the [Northeast
Pacific Basin](/wiki/Pacific_hurricane "Pacific hurricane"), or in [the North
Atlantic](/wiki/North_Atlantic_hurricane "North Atlantic hurricane"), it is
called a _hurricane_.[9] Neither "hurricane" nor "typhoon" is used in either
the Southern Hemisphere or the Indian Ocean. In these
[basins](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone_basins "Tropical cyclone basins"), storms of a
tropical nature are referred to as either tropical cyclones, severe tropical
cyclones or very intense tropical cyclones.

As indicated in the table below, each basin uses a separate [system of
terminology](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone_scales "Tropical cyclone scales"), which
can make comparisons between different basins difficult. In the Pacific Ocean,
hurricanes from the Central North Pacific sometimes cross the [180th
meridian](/wiki/180th_meridian "180th meridian") into the Northwest Pacific,
becoming typhoons (such as [Hurricane/Typhoon Ioke](/wiki/Hurricane_Ioke
"Hurricane Ioke") in 2006); on rare occasions, the reverse will occur.[118] It
should also be noted that typhoons with 1-minute sustained winds greater than
67 metres per second (m/s), over 150 miles per hour (240 km/h), are called
_Super Typhoons_ by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.[119]

#### Tropical depression

"Tropical Depression" redirects here. For the Filipino reggae band, see
[Tropical Depression (band)](/wiki/Tropical_Depression_\(band\) "Tropical
Depression \(band\)"). For the EP by Elephant Micah, see [Tropical Depression
(EP)](/wiki/Tropical_Depression_\(EP\) "Tropical Depression \(EP\)").

A tropical depression or tropical low is a tropical disturbance that has a
clearly defined [surface circulation](/wiki/Eye_\(cyclone\) "Eye \(cyclone\)")
with [maximum sustained winds](/wiki/Maximum_sustained_wind "Maximum sustained
wind") of less than 34 kn (39 mph; 63 km/h).[43] Within the Southern
Hemisphere, the depression can have gale force or stronger winds in one or
more quadrants, but not near the centre.[43]

#### Tropical storm

"Tropical Storm" redirects here. For the album, see [_Tropical Storm_
(album)](/wiki/Tropical_Storm_\(album\) "Tropical Storm \(album\)").

A **tropical storm** is an organized system of strong thunderstorms with a
defined surface circulation and maximum sustained winds between 34 knots (63
km/h) and 64 knots (119 km/h). At this point, the distinctive cyclonic shape
starts to develop, although an eye is not usually present. Government weather
services first assign names to systems that reach this intensity (thus the
term _named storm_).[120] Although tropical storms are less intense than a
hurricane they can produce significant damage. The shear force of winds can
blow off shingles, and air borne objects can cause damage to power lines,
roofing and siding. More dangerous is the heavy rainfall causing inland
flooding.[121]

#### Hurricane or typhoon

Main articles: [Atlantic hurricane](/wiki/Atlantic_hurricane "Atlantic
hurricane"), [Pacific hurricane](/wiki/Pacific_hurricane "Pacific hurricane"),
and [typhoon](/wiki/Typhoon "Typhoon")

A hurricane or typhoon (sometimes simply referred to as a tropical cyclone, as
opposed to a depression or storm) is a system with sustained winds of at least
34 m/s (66 kn; 76 mph; 120 km/h).[120] A cyclone of this intensity tends to
develop an eye, an area of relative calm (and lowest atmospheric pressure) at
the center of circulation. The eye is often visible in satellite images as a
small, circular, cloud-free spot. Surrounding the eye is the
[eyewall](/wiki/Eyewall "Eyewall"), an area about 16 kilometres (9.9 mi) to 80
kilometres (50 mi) wide in which the strongest
[thunderstorms](/wiki/Thunderstorm "Thunderstorm") and winds circulate around
the storm's center. Maximum sustained winds in the strongest tropical cyclones
have been estimated at about 95 m/s (185 kn; 210 mph; 340 km/h).[122]
