### Origin of storm terms

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/101.typhoon.altonthompson.jpg/250px-101.typhoon.altonthompson.jpg)](/wiki/File:101.typhoon.altonthompson.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:101.typhoon.altonthompson.jpg "Enlarge")

[Taipei 101](/wiki/Taipei_101 "Taipei 101") endures a typhoon in 2005

The word _typhoon_ , which is used today in the Northwest Pacific, may be
derived from [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language") _ţūfān_ (طوفان)
(similar in [Hindustani](/wiki/Hindustani_language "Hindustani language") and
[Persian](/wiki/Persian_language "Persian language")), which in turn
originates from [Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language")
_[Typhon](/wiki/Typhon "Typhon")_ (Τυφών), a monster from [Greek
mythology](/wiki/Greek_mythology "Greek mythology") associated with
storms.[123] The related [Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese
language") word _tufão_ , used in Portuguese for typhoons, is also derived
from _Typhon._[124][_[disputed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Disputed_statement
"Wikipedia:Disputed statement") (for: folk etymology?) –
[discuss](/wiki/Talk:Tropical_cyclone "Talk:Tropical cyclone")_] The word is
also similar to Chinese "táifēng" (Simplified Chinese: 台风, Traditional
Chinese: 颱風) (fēng = wind), "toifung" in [Cantonese](/wiki/Cantonese
"Cantonese"), "taifū" (台風) in Japanese, and "taepung" (태풍) in Korean.

The word _hurricane_ , used in the North Atlantic and Northeast Pacific, is
derived from _huracán_ , the Spanish word for the [Carib](/wiki/Island_Caribs
"Island Caribs")/[Taino](/wiki/Taino_people "Taino people") storm god,
[Juracán](/wiki/Jurac%C3%A1n "Juracán"). This god is believed by scholars to
have been at least partially derived from the [Mayan](/wiki/Maya_peoples "Maya
peoples") creator god, [Huracan](/wiki/Huracan "Huracan"). Huracan was
believed by the Maya to have created dry land out of the turbulent waters. The
god was also credited with later destroying the "wooden people", the
precursors to the "[maize people](/wiki/Maya_maize_god "Maya maize god")",
with an immense storm and flood.[125][126] Huracan is also the source of the
word _orcan_ , another word for a particularly strong [European
windstorm](/wiki/European_windstorm "European windstorm").[126]

### Naming

Main articles: [Tropical cyclone naming](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone_naming
"Tropical cyclone naming") and [History of tropical cyclone
naming](/wiki/History_of_tropical_cyclone_naming "History of tropical cyclone
naming")

The practice of using names to identify tropical cyclones goes back many
years, with systems named after places or things they hit before the formal
start of naming.[127][128] The system currently used provides positive
identification of severe weather systems in a brief form, that is readily
understood and recognized by the public.[127][128] The credit for the first
usage of personal names for weather systems is generally given to the
[Queensland Government](/wiki/Queensland_Government "Queensland Government")
Meteorologist [Clement Wragge](/wiki/Clement_Wragge "Clement Wragge") who
named systems between 1887 and 1907.[127][128] This system of naming weather
systems subsequently fell into disuse for several years after Wragge retired,
until it was revived in the latter part of [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II
"World War II") for the Western Pacific.[127][128] Formal naming schemes have
subsequently been introduced for the [North and South Atlantic, Eastern,
Central, Western and Southern Pacific basins](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone_basins
"Tropical cyclone basins") as well as the [Australian
region](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone_basins "Tropical cyclone basins") and [Indian
Ocean](/wiki/Indian_Ocean "Indian Ocean").[128]

At present tropical cyclones are officially named by one of eleven
meteorological services and retain their names throughout their lifetimes to
provide ease of communication between forecasters and the general public
regarding forecasts, watches, and warnings.[127] Since the systems can last a
week or longer and more than one can be occurring in the same basin at the
same time, the names are thought to reduce the confusion about what storm is
being described.[127] Names are assigned in order from predetermined
[lists](/wiki/Lists_of_tropical_cyclone_names "Lists of tropical cyclone
names") with one, three, or ten-minute sustained wind speeds of more than 65
km/h (40 mph) depending on which basin it originates.[39][41][42] However,
standards vary from basin to basin with some tropical depressions named in the
Western Pacific, while tropical cyclones have to have a significant amount of
[gale](/wiki/Gale "Gale")-force winds occurring around the center before they
are named within the [Southern Hemisphere](/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere "Southern
Hemisphere").[42][43] The names of significant tropical cyclones in the North
Atlantic Ocean, Pacific Ocean, and Australian region are retired from the
naming lists and replaced with another name.[39][40][43]

## Notable tropical cyclones

Main articles: [List of notable tropical
cyclones](/wiki/List_of_notable_tropical_cyclones "List of notable tropical
cyclones"), [List of Atlantic hurricanes](/wiki/List_of_Atlantic_hurricanes
"List of Atlantic hurricanes"), and [List of Pacific
hurricanes](/wiki/List_of_Pacific_hurricanes "List of Pacific hurricanes")

Tropical cyclones that cause extreme destruction are rare, although when they
occur, they can cause great amounts of damage or thousands of fatalities. The
[1970 Bhola cyclone](/wiki/1970_Bhola_cyclone "1970 Bhola cyclone") is the
deadliest tropical cyclone on record, killing more than 300,000 people[129]
and potentially as many as 1 million[130] after striking the densely populated
[Ganges Delta](/wiki/Ganges_Delta "Ganges Delta") region of
[Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh") on November 13, 1970. Its powerful
storm surge was responsible for the high death toll.[129] The [North Indian
cyclone basin](/wiki/List_of_North_Indian_Ocean_cyclone_seasons "List of North
Indian Ocean cyclone seasons") has historically been the deadliest
basin.[97][131] Elsewhere, [Typhoon Nina](/wiki/Typhoon_Nina_\(1975\) "Typhoon
Nina \(1975\)") killed nearly 100,000 in China in 1975 due to a [100-year
flood](/wiki/100-year_flood "100-year flood") that caused 62 dams including
the [Banqiao Dam](/wiki/Banqiao_Dam "Banqiao Dam") to fail.[132] The [Great
Hurricane of 1780](/wiki/Great_Hurricane_of_1780 "Great Hurricane of 1780") is
the deadliest [North Atlantic hurricane](/wiki/North_Atlantic_hurricane "North
Atlantic hurricane") on record, killing about 22,000 people in the [Lesser
Antilles](/wiki/Lesser_Antilles "Lesser Antilles").[133] A tropical cyclone
does not need to be particularly strong to cause memorable damage, primarily
if the deaths are from rainfall or mudslides. [Tropical Storm
Thelma](/wiki/Tropical_Storm_Thelma "Tropical Storm Thelma") in November 1991
killed thousands in the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines"),[134]
although the strongest typhoon to ever make landfall on record was [Typhoon
Haiyan](/wiki/Typhoon_Haiyan "Typhoon Haiyan") on November 2013, causing
widespread devastation in [Eastern Visayas](/wiki/Eastern_Visayas "Eastern
Visayas") and killing at least 6,300 people in that country alone. In 1982,
the unnamed tropical depression that eventually became [Hurricane
Paul](/wiki/Hurricane_Paul_\(1982\) "Hurricane Paul \(1982\)") killed around
1,000 people in [Central America](/wiki/Central_America "Central
America").[135]

[Hurricane Harvey](/wiki/Hurricane_Harvey "Hurricane Harvey") is estimated as
the costliest tropical cyclone worldwide,[136] with an estimated $198.6
billion in damages (2017 [USD](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States
dollar")). Harvey killed at least 90 people in August 2017 after making
[landfall](/wiki/Landfall "Landfall") in [Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas") as a
[low-end Category 4
hurricane](/wiki/List_of_Category_4_hurricanes#List_of_Category_4_hurricanes.232001-present
"List of Category 4 hurricanes"). [Hurricane Katrina](/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina
"Hurricane Katrina") is estimated as the second-costliest tropical cyclone
worldwide,[137] causing $81.2 billion in property damage (2008 USD)[138] with
overall damage estimates exceeding $100 billion (2005 USD).[137] Katrina
killed at least 1,836 people after striking [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana
"Louisiana") and [Mississippi](/wiki/Mississippi "Mississippi") as a [major
hurricane](/wiki/Tropical_cyclone_scales "Tropical cyclone scales") in August
2005.[138] [Hurricane Sandy](/wiki/Hurricane_Sandy "Hurricane Sandy") is the
third most destructive tropical cyclone in U.S history, with damage totaling
$68 billion (2012 USD), and with damage costs at $37.5 billion (2012 USD),
[Hurricane Ike](/wiki/Hurricane_Ike "Hurricane Ike") is the fourth most
destructive tropical cyclone in U.S history. The [Galveston Hurricane of
1900](/wiki/Galveston_Hurricane_of_1900 "Galveston Hurricane of 1900") is the
deadliest natural disaster in the United States, killing an estimated 6,000 to
12,000 people in [Galveston, Texas](/wiki/Galveston,_Texas "Galveston,
Texas").[139] [Hurricane Mitch](/wiki/Hurricane_Mitch "Hurricane Mitch")
caused more than 10,000 fatalities in [Central America](/wiki/Central_America
"Central America"), making it the second deadliest Atlantic hurricane in
history. [Hurricane Iniki](/wiki/Hurricane_Iniki "Hurricane Iniki") in 1992
was the most powerful storm to strike [Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii "Hawaii") in
recorded history, hitting [Kauai](/wiki/Kauai "Kauai") as a Category 4
hurricane, killing six people, and causing U.S. $3 billion in damage.[140]
Kauai was also struck by Hurricanes Dot (1959) and Iwa (1982) (see [List of
Hawaii hurricanes](/wiki/List_of_Hawaii_hurricanes "List of Hawaii
hurricanes")). Other destructive Eastern [Pacific
hurricanes](/wiki/Pacific_hurricane "Pacific hurricane") include
[Pauline](/wiki/Hurricane_Pauline "Hurricane Pauline") and
[Kenna](/wiki/Hurricane_Kenna "Hurricane Kenna"), both causing severe damage
after striking [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico") as major hurricanes.[141][142]
In March 2004, [Cyclone Gafilo](/wiki/Cyclone_Gafilo "Cyclone Gafilo") struck
northeastern [Madagascar](/wiki/Madagascar "Madagascar") as a powerful
cyclone, killing 74, affecting more than 200,000, and becoming the worst
cyclone to affect the nation for more than 20 years.[143]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4e/Typhoonsizes.jpg)](/wiki/File:Typhoonsizes.jpg)

The relative sizes of [Typhoon Tip](/wiki/Typhoon_Tip "Typhoon Tip"), [Cyclone
Tracy](/wiki/Cyclone_Tracy "Cyclone Tracy"), and the [Contiguous United
States](/wiki/Contiguous_United_States "Contiguous United States")

The most intense storm on record was [Typhoon Tip](/wiki/Typhoon_Tip "Typhoon
Tip") in the northwestern Pacific Ocean in 1979, which reached a minimum
pressure of 870 hectopascals (25.69 inHg) and maximum sustained wind speeds of
165 knots (85 m/s) or 190 miles per hour (310 km/h).[144] The highest maximum
sustained wind speed ever recorded was 185 knots (95 m/s) or 215 miles per
hour (345 km/h) in [Hurricane Patricia](/wiki/Hurricane_Patricia "Hurricane
Patricia") in 2015, which is the most intense cyclone ever recorded in the
Western Hemisphere.[145] [Typhoon Nancy](/wiki/Typhoon_Nancy_\(1961\) "Typhoon
Nancy \(1961\)") in 1961 also had recorded wind speeds of 185 knots (95 m/s)
or 215 miles per hour (346 km/h), but recent research indicates that wind
speeds from the 1940s to the 1960s were gauged too high, and this is no longer
considered the storm with the highest wind speeds on record.[122] Likewise, a
surface-level gust caused by [Typhoon Paka](/wiki/Typhoon_Paka "Typhoon Paka")
on [Guam](/wiki/Guam "Guam") in late 1997 was recorded at 205 knots (105 m/s)
or 235 miles per hour (378 km/h). Had it been confirmed, it would be the
strongest non-[tornadic](/wiki/Tornado "Tornado") wind ever recorded on the
Earth's surface, but the reading had to be discarded since the
[anemometer](/wiki/Anemometer "Anemometer") was damaged by the storm.[146] The
[World Meteorological Organization](/wiki/World_Meteorological_Organization
"World Meteorological Organization") established Barrow Island as the location
of the highest non-tornado related wind gust at 408 km/h (253 mph).[147] The
gust occurred on 10 April 1996, during [Severe Tropical Cyclone
Olivia](/wiki/Cyclone_Olivia "Cyclone Olivia") and is documented in the
Australian Meteorological and Oceanographic Journal.[148] In addition to being
the most intense tropical cyclone on record based on pressure, Tip was the
largest cyclone on record, with tropical storm-force winds 2,170 kilometres
(1,350 mi) in diameter. The smallest storm on record, [Tropical Storm
Marco](/wiki/Tropical_Storm_Marco_\(2008\) "Tropical Storm Marco \(2008\)"),
formed during October 2008, and made landfall in [Veracruz](/wiki/Veracruz
"Veracruz"). Marco generated tropical storm-force winds only 37 kilometres (23
mi) in diameter.[149]

[Hurricane John](/wiki/Hurricane_John_\(1994\) "Hurricane John \(1994\)") is
the longest-lasting tropical cyclone on record, lasting 31 days in
[1994](/wiki/1994_Pacific_hurricane_season "1994 Pacific hurricane season").
Before the advent of satellite imagery in 1961, however, many tropical
cyclones were underestimated in their durations.[150] John is also the
longest-tracked tropical cyclone in the Northern Hemisphere on record, which
had a path of 8,250 mi (13,280 km).[151] [Cyclone Rewa](/wiki/Cyclone_Rewa
"Cyclone Rewa") of the [1993–94 South
Pacific](/wiki/1993%E2%80%9394_South_Pacific_cyclone_season "1993–94 South
Pacific cyclone season") and [Australian
region](/wiki/1993%E2%80%9394_Australian_region_cyclone_season "1993–94
Australian region cyclone season") cyclone seasons had one of the longest
tracks observed within the Southern Hemisphere, traveling a distance of over
5,545 mi (8,920 km) during December 1993 and January 1994.[151]

## Changes caused by El Niño–Southern Oscillation

See also: [El Niño–Southern
Oscillation](/wiki/El_Ni%C3%B1o%E2%80%93Southern_Oscillation "El Niño–Southern
Oscillation")

Most tropical cyclones form on the side of the subtropical ridge closer to the
[equator](/wiki/Equator "Equator"), then move poleward past the ridge axis
before recurving into the main belt of the [Westerlies](/wiki/Westerlies
"Westerlies").[152] When the [subtropical ridge](/wiki/Subtropical_ridge
"Subtropical ridge") position shifts due to El Niño, so will the preferred
tropical cyclone tracks. Areas west of [Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan") and
[Korea](/wiki/Korea "Korea") tend to experience much fewer September–November
tropical cyclone impacts during [El Niño](/wiki/El_Ni%C3%B1o "El Niño") and
neutral years. During El Niño years, the break in the subtropical ridge tends
to lie near [130°E](/wiki/130th_meridian_east "130th meridian east") which
would favor the Japanese archipelago.[153] During El Niño years,
[Guam](/wiki/Guam "Guam")'s chance of a tropical cyclone impact is one-third
more likely than of the long-term average.[154] The tropical Atlantic Ocean
experiences depressed activity due to increased vertical [wind
shear](/wiki/Wind_shear "Wind shear") across the region during El Niño
years.[155] During [La Niña](/wiki/La_Ni%C3%B1a "La Niña") years, the
formation of tropical cyclones, along with the subtropical ridge position,
shifts westward across the western Pacific Ocean, which increases the landfall
threat to [China](/wiki/China "China") and much greater intensity in the
[Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines").[153]

## Long-term activity trends

See also: [Atlantic hurricane reanalysis](/wiki/Atlantic_hurricane_reanalysis
"Atlantic hurricane reanalysis")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/NOAA_ACE_index_1950-2004_RGB.svg/250px-
NOAA_ACE_index_1950-2004_RGB.svg.png)](/wiki/File:NOAA_ACE_index_1950-2004_RGB.svg)

[](/wiki/File:NOAA_ACE_index_1950-2004_RGB.svg "Enlarge")

Atlantic Multidecadal Cycle since 1950, using [accumulated cyclone
energy](/wiki/Accumulated_cyclone_energy "Accumulated cyclone energy") (ACE)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Amo_timeseries_1856-present.svg/250px-
Amo_timeseries_1856-present.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Amo_timeseries_1856-present.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Amo_timeseries_1856-present.svg "Enlarge")

Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation Timeseries, 1856–2013

While the number of storms in the Atlantic has increased since 1995, there is
no obvious global trend; the annual number of tropical cyclones worldwide
remains about 87 ± 10 (Between 77 and 97 tropical cyclones annually). However,
the ability of climatologists to make long-term data analysis in certain
basins is limited by the lack of reliable historical data in some basins,
primarily in the Southern Hemisphere,[156] while noting that a significant
downward trend in tropical cyclone numbers has been identified for the region
near Australia (based on high quality data and accounting for the influence of
the El Niño-Southern Oscillation).[157] In spite of that, there is some
evidence that the intensity of hurricanes is increasing. [Kerry
Emanuel](/wiki/Kerry_Emanuel "Kerry Emanuel") stated, "Records of hurricane
activity worldwide show an upswing of both the maximum wind speed in and the
duration of hurricanes. The energy released by the average hurricane (again
considering all hurricanes worldwide) seems to have increased by around 70% in
the past 30 years or so, corresponding to about a 15% increase in the maximum
wind speed and a 60% increase in storm lifetime."[158]

Atlantic storms are becoming more destructive financially, as evidenced by the
fact that five of the ten [most expensive storms in United States
history](/wiki/List_of_costliest_Atlantic_hurricanes#Listed_by_cost_.28United_States_only.29
"List of costliest Atlantic hurricanes") have occurred since 1990. According
to the [World Meteorological
Organization](/wiki/World_Meteorological_Organization "World Meteorological
Organization"), "recent increase in societal impact from tropical cyclones has
been caused largely by rising concentrations of population and infrastructure
in coastal regions."[159] Political scientist
[Pielke](/wiki/Roger_A._Pielke_Jr. "Roger A. Pielke Jr.") _et al._ (2008)
normalized mainland US hurricane damage from 1900–2005 to 2005 values and
found no remaining trend of increasing absolute damage. The 1970s and 1980s
were notable because of the extremely low amounts of damage compared to other
decades. The decade 1996–2005 was the second most damaging among the past 11
decades, with only the decade 1926–1935 surpassing its costs.

Often in part because of the threat of hurricanes, many coastal regions had
sparse population between major ports until the advent of automobile tourism;
therefore, the most severe portions of hurricanes striking the coast may have
gone unmeasured in some instances. The combined effects of ship destruction
and remote landfall severely limit the number of intense hurricanes in the
official record before the era of hurricane reconnaissance aircraft and
satellite meteorology. Although the record shows a distinct increase in the
number and strength of intense hurricanes, therefore, experts regard the early
data as suspect.[160]

The number and strength of Atlantic hurricanes may undergo a 50–70 year cycle,
also known as the [Atlantic Multidecadal
Oscillation](/wiki/Atlantic_Multidecadal_Oscillation "Atlantic Multidecadal
Oscillation"). Nyberg _et al._ reconstructed Atlantic major hurricane activity
back to the early 18th century and found five periods averaging 3–5 major
hurricanes per year and lasting 40–60 years, and six other averaging 1.5–2.5
major hurricanes per year and lasting 10–20 years. These periods are
associated with the Atlantic multidecadal oscillation. Throughout, a decadal
oscillation related to solar irradiance was responsible for
enhancing/dampening the number of major hurricanes by 1–2 per year.[161]

Although more common since 1995, few above-normal hurricane seasons occurred
during 1970–94.[162] Destructive hurricanes struck frequently from 1926 to
1960, including many major [New England](/wiki/New_England "New England")
hurricanes. Twenty-one Atlantic tropical storms formed in
[1933](/wiki/1933_Atlantic_hurricane_season "1933 Atlantic hurricane season"),
a record only recently exceeded in [2005](/wiki/2005_Atlantic_hurricane_season
"2005 Atlantic hurricane season"), which saw 28 storms. Tropical hurricanes
occurred infrequently during the seasons of 1900–25; however, many intense
storms formed during 1870–99. During the [1887
season](/wiki/1887_Atlantic_hurricane_season "1887 Atlantic hurricane
season"), 19 tropical storms formed, of which a record 4 occurred after
November 1 and 11 strengthened into hurricanes. Few hurricanes occurred in the
1840s to 1860s; however, many struck in the early 19th century, including an
[1821 storm](/wiki/1821_Norfolk_and_Long_Island_hurricane "1821 Norfolk and
Long Island hurricane") that made a direct hit on [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"). Some historical weather experts
say these storms may have been as high as [Category 4](/wiki/Saffir-
Simpson_Hurricane_Scale "Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale") in strength.[163]

These active hurricane seasons predated satellite coverage of the Atlantic
basin. Before the satellite era began in 1960, tropical storms or hurricanes
went undetected unless a reconnaissance aircraft encountered one, a ship
reported a voyage through the storm, or a storm hit land in a populated
area.[160]

Proxy records based on [paleotempestological](/wiki/Paleotempestology
"Paleotempestology") research have revealed that major hurricane activity
along the [Gulf of Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico") coast varies
on timescales of centuries to millennia.[164][165] Few major hurricanes struck
the Gulf coast during 3000–1400 BC and again during the most recent
millennium. These quiescent intervals were separated by a hyperactive period
during 1400 BC and 1000 AD, when the Gulf coast was struck frequently by
catastrophic hurricanes and their landfall probabilities increased by 3–5
times. This millennial-scale variability has been attributed to long-term
shifts in the position of the [Azores High](/wiki/Azores_High "Azores
High"),[165] which may also be linked to changes in the strength of the [North
Atlantic oscillation](/wiki/North_Atlantic_oscillation "North Atlantic
oscillation").[166]

According to the Azores High hypothesis, an anti-phase pattern is expected to
exist between the Gulf of Mexico coast and the Atlantic coast. During the
quiescent periods, a more northeasterly position of the Azores High would
result in more hurricanes being steered towards the Atlantic coast. During the
hyperactive period, more hurricanes were steered towards the Gulf coast as the
Azores High was shifted to a more southwesterly position near the Caribbean.
Such a displacement of the Azores High is consistent with paleoclimatic
evidence that shows an abrupt onset of a drier climate in [Haiti](/wiki/Haiti
"Haiti") around 3200 [14C](/wiki/Radiocarbon_dating "Radiocarbon dating")
years BP,[167] and a change towards more humid conditions in the [Great
Plains](/wiki/Great_Plains "Great Plains") during the late-Holocene as more
moisture was pumped up the [Mississippi Valley](/wiki/Mississippi_Valley
"Mississippi Valley") through the Gulf coast. Preliminary data from the
northern Atlantic coast seem to support the Azores High hypothesis. A
3000-year proxy record from a coastal lake in [Cape Cod](/wiki/Cape_Cod "Cape
Cod") suggests that hurricane activity increased significantly during the past
500–1000 years, just as the Gulf coast was amid a quiescent period of the last
millennium.

## Climate change

Main article: [Tropical cyclones and climate
change](/wiki/Tropical_cyclones_and_climate_change "Tropical cyclones and
climate change")

The 2007 [IPCC](/wiki/IPCC "IPCC") report noted many observed changes in the
climate, including atmospheric composition, global average temperatures, ocean
conditions, and others. The report concluded the observed increase in tropical
cyclone intensity is larger than climate models predict. In addition, the
report considered that it is likely that storm intensity will continue to
increase through the 21st century, and declared it more likely than not that
there has been some human contribution to the increases in tropical cyclone
intensity.[168]

P.J. Webster and others published in 2005 an article in
_[Science](/wiki/Science_\(journal\) "Science \(journal\)")_ examining the
"changes in tropical cyclone number, duration, and intensity" over the past 35
years, the period when satellite data has been available. Their main finding
was although the number of cyclones decreased throughout the planet excluding
the north [Atlantic Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean"), there was a
great increase in the number and proportion of very strong cyclones.[169]

According to 2006 studies by the [National Oceanic and Atmospheric
Administration](/wiki/National_Oceanic_and_Atmospheric_Administration
"National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration"), "the strongest hurricanes
in the present climate may be upstaged by even more intense hurricanes over
the next century as the earth's climate is warmed by increasing levels of
greenhouse gases in the atmosphere".[170]

Studies published since 2008, by [Kerry Emanuel](/wiki/Kerry_Emanuel "Kerry
Emanuel") from MIT, indicate that [global warming](/wiki/Global_warming
"Global warming") is likely to increase the intensity but decrease the
frequency of hurricane and cyclone activity.[171] In an article in
_[Nature](/wiki/Nature_\(journal\) "Nature \(journal\)")_ , Kerry Emanuel
stated that potential hurricane destructiveness, a measure combining hurricane
strength, duration, and frequency, "is highly correlated with tropical sea
surface temperature, reflecting well-documented climate signals, including
[multidecadal oscillations](/wiki/Climate_oscillation "Climate oscillation")
in the North Atlantic and North Pacific, and global warming". Emanuel
predicted "a substantial increase in hurricane-related losses in the twenty-
first century".[172]

Research reported in the September 3, 2008 issue of _Nature_ found that the
strongest tropical cyclones are getting stronger, in particular over the North
Atlantic and Indian oceans. Wind speeds for the strongest tropical storms
increased from an average of 225 km/h (140 mph) in 1981 to 251 km/h (156 mph)
in 2006, while the ocean temperature, averaged globally over all the regions
where tropical cyclones form, increased from 28.2 °C (82.8 °F) to 28.5 °C
(83.3 °F) during this period.[173][174]

A 2017 study looked at compounding effects from floods, storm surge, and
terrestrial flooding (rivers), and projects an increase [due to global
warming](/wiki/Effects_of_global_warming "Effects of global
warming").[175][176]

## Related cyclone types

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Gustav_09_sep_2002_1805Z.jpg/250px-
Gustav_09_sep_2002_1805Z.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gustav_09_sep_2002_1805Z.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gustav_09_sep_2002_1805Z.jpg "Enlarge")

Gustav on September 9, 2002, the first system to be given a name as a
subtropical cyclone

See also: [Cyclone](/wiki/Cyclone "Cyclone"), [Extratropical
cyclone](/wiki/Extratropical_cyclone "Extratropical cyclone"), and
[Subtropical cyclone](/wiki/Subtropical_cyclone "Subtropical cyclone")

In addition to tropical cyclones, there are two other classes of cyclones
within the spectrum of cyclone types. These kinds of cyclones, known as
[extratropical cyclones](/wiki/Extratropical_cyclone "Extratropical cyclone")
and [subtropical cyclones](/wiki/Subtropical_cyclone "Subtropical cyclone"),
can be stages a tropical cyclone passes through during its
[formation](/wiki/Tropical_cyclogenesis "Tropical cyclogenesis") or
dissipation.[177] An _extratropical cyclone_ is a storm that derives energy
from horizontal temperature differences, which are typical in higher
latitudes. A tropical cyclone can become extratropical as it moves toward
higher latitudes if its energy source changes from heat released by
condensation to differences in temperature between air masses; although not as
frequently, an extratropical cyclone can transform into a subtropical storm,
and from there into a tropical cyclone.[178] From space, extratropical storms
have a characteristic "[comma](/wiki/Comma_\(punctuation\) "Comma
\(punctuation\)")-shaped" cloud pattern.[179] Extratropical cyclones can also
be dangerous when their low-pressure centers cause powerful winds and high
seas.[180]

A _subtropical cyclone_ is a [weather](/wiki/Weather "Weather") system that
has some characteristics of a tropical cyclone and some characteristics of an
extratropical cyclone. They can form in a wide band of
[latitudes](/wiki/Latitude "Latitude"), from the [equator](/wiki/Equator
"Equator") to 50°. Although subtropical storms rarely have hurricane-force
winds, they may become tropical in nature as their cores warm.[181] From an
operational standpoint, a tropical cyclone is usually not considered to become
subtropical during its extratropical transition.[182]

## Popular culture

Main article: [Tropical cyclones in popular
culture](/wiki/Tropical_cyclones_in_popular_culture "Tropical cyclones in
popular culture")

In [popular culture](/wiki/Popular_culture "Popular culture"), tropical
cyclones have made several appearances in different types of media, including
films, books, television, music, and [electronic games](/wiki/Electronic_game
"Electronic game").[183] These media often portray tropical cyclones that are
either entirely [fictional](/wiki/Fiction "Fiction") or based on real
events.[183] For example, [George Rippey Stewart](/wiki/George_Rippey_Stewart
"George Rippey Stewart")'s _[Storm](/wiki/Storm_\(novel\) "Storm \(novel\)")_
, a [best-seller](/wiki/Best-seller "Best-seller") published in 1941, is
thought to have influenced meteorologists on their decision to assign female
names to Pacific tropical cyclones.[128] Another example is the hurricane in
_[The Perfect Storm](/wiki/The_Perfect_Storm_\(film\) "The Perfect Storm
\(film\)")_ , which describes the sinking of the _[Andrea
Gail](/wiki/Andrea_Gail "Andrea Gail")_ by the [1991 Perfect
Storm](/wiki/1991_Perfect_Storm "1991 Perfect Storm").[184] Hypothetical
hurricanes have been featured in parts of the plots of series such as _[The
Simpsons](/wiki/Hurricane_Neddy "Hurricane Neddy")_ ,
_[Invasion](/wiki/Invasion_\(TV_series\) "Invasion \(TV series\)")_ , _[Family
Guy](/wiki/One_If_by_Clam,_Two_If_by_Sea "One If by Clam, Two If by Sea")_ ,
_[Seinfeld](/wiki/The_Checks "The Checks")_ , _[Dawson's
Creek](/wiki/Dawson%27s_Creek "Dawson's Creek")_, _[Burn
Notice](/wiki/Burn_Notice "Burn Notice")_ and _[CSI:
Miami](/wiki/CSI:_Miami_\(season_2\) "CSI: Miami \(season
2\)")_.[183][185][186][187][188][189] The 2004 film _[The Day After
Tomorrow](/wiki/The_Day_After_Tomorrow "The Day After Tomorrow")_ includes
several mentions of actual tropical cyclones and features fantastical
"hurricane-like", albeit non-tropical, Arctic storms.[190][191]

qa.question: where does a tropical cyclone or hurricane get its energy
qa.answer: ['through the evaporation of water from the ocean surface, which ultimately recondenses into clouds and rain when moist air rises and cools to saturation']
